answers.answer: Missy, Autism is a social disorder so if the child has a normal social friendships I would say that it is not autism.  I don't really have any experience with tourettes but it does seem like she may have something similar.  I think that it is important to tell your daughter that this friend may have some type of disability and it is something that she cannot help.  She needs understanding, not fear.  This may be how this child deals with stress and processes information.  Since I have a severely autistic child I applaud parents who teach their children that people who are different need understanding and acceptance.  They did not choose to be different, it is no different than someone who has cancer or diabetes but for some reason mental issues are considered scarier than other problems.Thanks for caring enough to ask.  Dawn - Paul's Mom

question: My daughter has a friend who is constantly twirling her hair and carrying on a conversation with herself with a very rapid speech. You can't understand what she is saying but her hands are constantly twirling around her face and the top of her head.  I guess in the public school system, you tend to see a lot of issues.  When reading a poem outloud, her voice changes and her rate of speed does as well.  My daughter is asking me what it is, b/c they are at an age where they notice the behavior of this child and I have no clue what to tell her.  It is a behavior that she can't control and that is obvious.  She has normal social friendships and appears very bright.
title: Is this tourettes or more of an autistic trait?
